repnme.cdata!:
Kenya - Total War Against HIV and AIDS
            (TOWA) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Total War Against HIV and AIDS
            (TOWA) Project for Kenya received a satisfactory outcome
            rating with substantial risk to development outcome. Both
            the Bank and the Borrower received satisfactory performance
            ratings respectively. The first (level 2) restructuring: (i)
            reallocated funds to continue to enable the increased
            disbursement percentage from IDA to adjust for planned DFIF
            co-financing not becoming available, and (ii) enabled the
            urgent purchase of additional bed nets for the malaria
            program. The second (level-1) restructuring was to: (i) make
            up for the funds from Department for International
            Development (DFID), which was not going to be available as
            co-financing, to fund the fourth and fifth call for proposal
            (CfPs); (ii) allocate another significant amount to scale up
            the malaria bed net program and help attain universal
            coverage of bed nets in the high malaria risk areas of the
            country; (iii) support the project restructuring and restore
            some of the funding, and (iv) extend the project for another
            18 months, particularly to continue fiduciary and monitoring
            and evaluation strengthening, and to achieve the revised
            PDO. The third restructuring (level 2) was to extend the
            closing date 6 months to allow for: (i) full implementation
            without compromising quality of activities; (ii)
            implementation of actions to address specific needs of
            indigenous people (IPs) and revision of the project
            implementation manual; (iii) reallocation of resources to
            activities needing additional funds and to ensure
            utilization of the remaining credit. The fourth
            restructuring (level 2) was to extend the closing date by
            another 6 months to enable: (i) final completion of project
            activities at an advanced stage, delayed when the government
            introduced changes in the financial system in keeping with
            the new constitution that resulted in substantial delays in
            getting funds to the project; (ii) reallocation of funds to
            enable full utilization of the remaining credit. Several
            lessons were learned from this project including the
            following: (1) realistic independent assessment of project
            progress is an effective mechanism that improves project
            management and service delivery, (2) using independent
            fiduciary and monitoring agents helps to identify problems
            of inappropriate use of disbursed funds early on, (3) when
            grassroots communities are facing crisis, it is possible to
            turn the crises into opportunities for improving lives in
            the community, and (4) streamlining institutional
            arrangements and roles during project design, and providing
            needed training to fulfill roles is a necessity for avoiding
            implementation delays.

repnme.cdata!:
Kenya - Total War against HIV and AIDS
            (TOWA) Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Total
            War against HIV and AIDS (TOWA) Project for Kenya is to
            assist Kenya to expand the coverage of targeted Human
            Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) and Acquired Immune Deficiency
            Syndrome (AIDS) prevention and mitigation interventions.
            This would be done through: (i) sustaining the improved
            institutional performance of the National AIDS Control
            Council (NACC); and (ii) supporting the implementation of
            the Kenya National AIDS Strategic Plan (KNASP). The project
            implementation has recently slowed down due to funds flow
            problems. Consequently, the project is unlikely to disburse
            funds to Central Statistics Organization (CSO) selected
            under the last round of call for proposals.  An extension
            will allow full implementation of activities by these CSOs
            which have already been contracted to complete their tasks
            without compromising on quality.   The extension will also
            allow the project to implement actions to address specific
            needs of Indigenous People based on the recently completed
            consultations. The project grant manual will be revised to
            address the needs of Indigenous People as the normal call
            for proposal is unlikely to meet the needs of this special
            group. Further, this will also allow the project to complete
            the Impact evaluation being undertaken with technical
            assistance from the Bank which was delayed due to longer
            than originally envisaged time taken for contracting the
            survey firms. This impact evaluation will provide valuable
            lessons on innovative approaches for HIV/AIDS prevention.

            (TOWA) Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Total
            War against HIV and AIDS (TOWA) Project for Kenya is to
            assist Kenya to expand the coverage of targeted Human
            Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) and Acquired Immune Deficiency
            Syndrome (AIDS) prevention and mitigation interventions.
            This would be done through: (i) sustaining the improved
            institutional performance of the National AIDS Control
            Council (NACC); and (ii) supporting the implementation of
            the Kenya National AIDS Strategic Plan (KNASP). The project
            implementation has recently slowed down due to funds flow
            problems. Consequently, the project is unlikely to disburse
            funds to Central Statistics Organization (CSO) selected
            under the last round of call for proposals.  An extension
            will allow full implementation of activities by these CSOs
            which have already been contracted to complete their tasks
            without compromising on quality.   The extension will also
            allow the project to implement actions to address specific
            needs of Indigenous People based on the recently completed
            consultations. The project grant manual will be revised to
            address the needs of Indigenous People as the normal call
            for proposal is unlikely to meet the needs of this special
            group. Further, this will also allow the project to complete
            the Impact evaluation being undertaken with technical
            assistance from the Bank which was delayed due to longer
            than originally envisaged time taken for contracting the
            survey firms. This impact evaluation will provide valuable
            lessons on innovative approaches for HIV/AIDS prevention.
